'''2012''': Bioceutica | num_employees = 20,000 salespeople | num_employees_year = 2010 | parent = | website = [https://web.archive.org/web/20090629215347/http://www.trumpnetwork.com/ Official website] }} '''The Trump Network''' was a [[multi-level marketing]] company named after businessman and current [[U.S. President]] [[Donald Trump]]. The company, which sold vitamins and health products, was initially founded as Ideal Health in 1997, before being renamed in 2009 as part of a licensing agreement between Trump and the owners. The licensing agreement expired at the end of 2011, and the company's remaining assets were sold to Bioceutica the following year. ==History== ===Ideal Health=== Ideal Health, Inc. was founded as a [[multi-level marketing]] company in March 1997.{{cite web|title=The Founders|url=http://www.idealhealth.com:80/Company/Founders.aspx|publisher=Ideal Health, Inc.|accessdate=July 13, 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051123233635/http://www.idealhealth.com/Company/Founders.aspx|archivedate=November 23, 2005|deadurl=yes|df=}}{{cite web|url= https://www.businessforhome.org/2012/02/the-trump-network-lawsuit-going-down-fast/|title= The Trump Network Lawsuit – Going Down Fast?|last= Nuyten|first= Ted|date= February 1, 2012|website= Business for Home|access-date=July 12, 2017|quote=In March of 1997, Ideal Health started [...].}} The company, headquartered in [[Lynnfield, Massachusetts]],{{cite web|title=Contact us|url=http://www.idealhealth.com:80/contact.htm|publisher=Ideal Health Systems, Inc.|accessdate=July 13, 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20010203222300/http://www.idealhealth.com/contact.htm|archivedate=February 3, 2001|deadurl=yes|df=}} was founded by Lou DeCaprio and brothers Scott and Todd Stanwood, who were friends of DeCaprio. The three men had previously opened New England Wine and Spirits in [[Newburyport, Massachusetts]] in 1991. After the Stanwoods' sister had joined a direct sales company in 1989, she encouraged them to get involved in the industry. The three men worked for [[Nu Skin Enterprises]], a multi-level marketing company, and decided to form Ideal Health after seeing how successful Nu Skin had become. Ideal Health hired salespeople who would then conduct their own marketing to sell a customized vitamin supplement program, which was determined through a [[urinalysis]] test to learn about the customer's health. Salespeople made money through [[Commission (remuneration)|commission]] on sales and by recruiting other salespeople. The products were shipped directly to customers rather than being stored by company salespeople.{{cite news|last=Cohn|first=Ari|title=Chandler teacher turns to Trump in lean times|url=http://www.eastvalleytribune.com/news/chandler-teacher-turns-to-trump-in-lean-times/article_02293d77-9a11-56ca-b62f-0a22324f6889.html|accessdate=July 12, 2017|work=[[East Valley Tribune]]|date=July 12, 2009}} By 2004, numerous complaints had been filed with the [[Federal Trade Commission]] (FTC) against Ideal Health, by salespeople who alleged that they spent thousands of dollars on company products that did not generate revenue. One of Ideal Health's products, Supreme Greens, was the subject of an FTC lawsuit for its false claim of being able to cure cancer. In 2004, Ideal Health acquired and began selling a line of skin-care products known as BIO Essentials. ===The Trump Network=== In 2008 Donald Trump began searching for a [[Multi-level marketing|network marketing]] company with which to become associated. Trump's lawyer Jerry Schrager met DeCaprio during a business presentation that DeCaprio was doing in New York City.{{cite news|last=Pressler|first=Jessica|title="If I Can't Trust Donald Trump, Who Can I Trust?" The Donald has a new scheme. Seller beware.|url=http://nymag.com/news/business/70831/|accessdate=July 12, 2017|work=[[New York (magazine)|New York]]|date=January 23, 2011|pages=1–4}} At the time, Ideal Health was seeking a partnership to increase its recognition. Trump met with DeCaprio and the Stanwoods at [[Trump Tower]] in Manhattan. Trump later recalled, "We hit it off. I checked into their past, and they were solid people. They had a nice track record, but even more importantly they had a lot of people who thought highly of them." In March 2009 Trump agreed to license his name to the company, which would be re-branded as The Trump Network. Trump also agreed to make occasional appearances at events to promote the company's products. Trump had initially considered taking a financial stake in the company. DeCaprio remained as the [[President (corporate title)|president]] of the company, while Todd Stanwood served as the [[chief executive officer]] and Scott Stanwood served as the vice president of communications. The Trump Network launched on November 13, 2009, with a ceremony attended by Trump and held at the Hyatt Regency hotel{{cite news|last1=Nobile|first1=Phil|title=Donald Trump's biggest business hits and misses|url=http://www.newsday.com/business/donald-trump-s-biggest-business-hits-and-misses-includes-trump-steaks-the-apprentice-1.11614966|accessdate=July 12, 2017|work=[[Newsday]]|date=February 25, 2017}} in downtown [[Miami]].{{cite news|last=McConville|first=Christine|title=Newbury vitamin company gets boost with Donald Trump as partner|url=http://www.bostonherald.com/business/business_markets/2009/11/newbury_vitamin_company_gets_boost_donald_trump_partner|accessdate=July 12, 2017|work=[[Boston Herald]]|date=November 20, 2009}}{{cite news|last=|first=|title=The Donald in Destin: As Trump Network forms, can towers be far behind?|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/|accessdate=July 12, 2017|work=The Destin Log|date=November 18, 2009|url-access=subscription|via=[[NewsBank]]|quote=McKinney attended the official launch of The Trump Network, which was attended by The Donald himself, in Miami on Nov. 13.}} Trump referred to the company as a "rescue and recovery program" for people who were suffering from the effects of the [[Great Recession in the United States|Great Recession]] and who needed extra income. For $48 people who wanted to be salespeople could buy a marketing kit and three months of access to a personalized web site to promote the company products. Also available was a $497 package that also included coupons, CDs, and sales tips. Marketers had the right to sell any unsold inventory back to the company.{{cite news|last=Lush|first=Tamara|title=Donald Trump wants you to sell his nutrition products|url=https://www.thestar.com/business/2009/11/19/donald_trump_wants_you_to_sell_his_nutrition_products.html|accessdate=July 12, 2017|work=The Star|agency=Associated Press|date=November 19, 2009}} Packaging for the company's products was imprinted with Trump's family crest, but the lineup of products remained mostly the same. Trump created a scientific advisory committee to evaluate the products sold by the company. Trump also registered 18 negative Internet [[domain name]]s, including TrumpNetworkFraud.com and DonaldTrumpPonziScheme.com, to prevent websites from being registered with those names.{{cite news|last=Sisak|first=Micharl R.|title=Trump is master of his domains, even ones that bash him|url=https://apnews.com/2c17b3bf329147a4bcf92ec6f3dfa2d7/trump-master-his-domains-even-ones-bash-him|accessdate=July 12, 2017|agency=Associated Press|date=November 1, 2016|quote=Trump and his team didn't take any chances in 2009 when he created the Trump Network brand to sell vitamins and other health products. They quietly scooped up 18 negative domain names, including DonaldTrumpPonziScheme.com and TrumpNetworkFraud.com.}} As of March 2010 Trump Network products were available in each U.S. state, with plans to expand to other countries. By then the company had relocated to a larger building at 428 [[Newburyport Turnpike]] in [[Rowley, Massachusetts]].{{cite news|last=Curley Katzman|first=Katie|title=Trump builds a new empire... in Rowley|url=http://www.eagletribune.com/news/local_news/trump-builds-a-new-empire-in-rowley/article_bc1436c9-9ec8-5219-babf-d06a546c9aee.html|accessdate=July 12, 2017|work=[[The Eagle-Tribune]]|date=March 22, 2010}}{{cite web|title=The Trump Network|url=https://www.linkedin.com/company/the-trump-network_13|website=LinkedIn|accessdate=July 12, 2017}} The company had previously been headquartered at 12 Kent Way in [[Byfield, Massachusetts]].{{cite web|title=The Trump Network Corporate Headquarters|url=http://www.trumpnetwork.com:80/Contact/Default.aspx|publisher=The Trump Network|accessdate=July 12, 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090629050008/http://www.trumpnetwork.com/Contact/Default.aspx|archivedate=June 29, 2009|deadurl=yes|df=}} The presence of Trump's surname increased the number of salespeople who signed up with the company.{{cite news|last=Ailworth|first=Erin|title=Firm's new moniker may be its Trump card: After partnering with the Donald, the former Ideal Health takes off|url=http://archive.boston.com/business/articles/2010/12/07/firms_new_moniker_may_be_its_trump_card/|accessdate=July 12, 2017|work=[[The Boston Globe]]|date=December 7, 2010}} By December 2010, the company had grown 373 percent since Trump became involved,{{cite web |url= http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/nbcs-the-apprentice-leads-candidates-to-the-trump-network-111679704.html|title= NBC's The Apprentice Leads Candidates to The Trump Network|date= December 10, 2010|website= [[PR Newswire]]|access-date=July 12, 2017}} and had doubled its staff to approximately 50, with an additional 20,000 salespeople worldwide, up from 5,000 people prior to Trump's involvement. The company stated that revenue, at that time, was nearly $40 million. Stephanie Castagnier, Liza Mucheru-Wisner, and Steuart Martens, who were candidates on the [[The Apprentice (U.S. season 10)|tenth season]] of Trump's [[reality television]] series, ''[[The Apprentice (U.S. TV series)|The Apprentice]]'', became salespeople for The Trump Network.{{cite news|last=Tine|first=Victor|title='Apprentice' makes house call in Rowley|url=http://www.newburyportnews.com/news/local_news/apprentice-makes-house-call-in-rowley/article_e2a9276a-5986-5fbb-92aa-4e9577dc7317.html|accessdate=July 12, 2017|work=Newburyport News|date=October 13, 2010}} As of January 2011, The Trump Network had plans to add additional products and expand to Europe and Asia, while Trump hoped for the company to ultimately become larger than [[Amway]], its largest competitor. That month, DeCaprio addressed claims that salespeople were not earning money through the company: "Many times, if people aren't having success in recruiting, it has to do with not believing in themselves." Trump stated, "This is supposed to be a second income for people. This is not about them quitting their job. [Though] for some of them, it ''might'' lead to that." In late 2011, Trump's licensing contract with the company ended.{{cite news|last=Swanson|first=Ana|title=The Trump Network sought to make people rich, but left behind disappointment|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/wonk/wp/2016/03/23/the-trump-network-sought-to-make-people-rich-but-left-behind-disappointment/|accessdate=July 12, 2017|work=[[The Washington Post]]|date=March 23, 2016}} Bioceutica purchased the Trump Network's assets in early 2012 for an undisclosed amount of money,{{cite news|title=Exactly How Bogus Were Those 'Trump Vitamins?'|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/healthline-/exactly-how-bogus-were-th_b_10268610.html|accessdate=July 12, 2017|work=[[The Huffington Post]]|date=June 2, 2016}}{{cite news|last=Tuttle|first=Ian|title=Add Another Yuuge Failure to Trump's Pile: The Trump Network|url=http://www.nationalreview.com/article/432468/trump-networks-failure-harmed-small-investors|accessdate=July 12, 2017|work=[[National Review]]|date=March 8, 2016}} marking the end of the company. Some salespeople were disappointed to learn that Trump did not have a larger role in the company. In January 2016, Scott Stanwood declined to discuss the company because of confidentiality agreements. Trump's lawyer, Alan Garten, said many salespeople did "very well" and noted that Trump's role in the company was limited to the licensing of his surname and to providing motivational speeches to salespeople: "Anyone who claims that they were not aware of the extent of Mr. Trump's role is lying to himself." The company's website had included a disclaimer that read, "The Trump Network is not owned nor are any products sold over 'The Trump Network' developed or manufactured by Donald J. Trump or any entity owned or controlled by Donald J. Trump."{{cite news|title=Losses, regrets and questions at companies Trump endorsed|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/business/ct-trump-companies-20160127-story.html|accessdate=July 12, 2017|work=[[Chicago Tribune]]|date=January 27, 2016}} Garten later stated that Trump's role "was clearly disclosed, to everyone involved in the company and its members, whether it be in the member's independent contractor agreements, the marketing materials, or on the products themselves." ==Products== As of 2011, The Trump Network offered two multivitamins: Prime Essentials and Custom Essentials, the latter being more expensive. Custom Essentials used a urinalyses test known as PrivaTest to determine the vitamins required by each customer. At the time, Trump Network also offered children's health snacks known as Snazzle Snaxxs, as well as QuikStik [[energy drink]]s and a diet program known as Silhouette Solutions. After Trump became involved, the company added a line of skin-care products known as BioCé Cosmeceuticals. As of July 2017, the PrivaTest was still available via Bioceutica's website. Some nutritional experts noted that there was no evidence that the vitamins provided any benefits to people who consumed them; they also criticized the PrivaTest, stating that no urine test can reveal whether a person has a vitamin deficiency. [[Harvard University]] doctor Pieter Cohen considered the PrivaTest to be a "scam," calling it "a bogus program to make profit for the people who are selling it. It's fantasy."{{cite news|last1=Haglage|first1=Abby|last2=Mak|first2=Tim|title=Trump Vitamins Were Fortified With B.S.|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/trump-vitamins-were-fortified-with-bs|accessdate=July 12, 2017|work=[[The Daily Beast]]|date=May 25, 2016}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20051130040030/http://idealhealth.com/ Ideal Health official website], archived via the [[Wayback Machine]] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20090629215347/http://www.trumpnetwork.com/ Trump Network official website], archived via the Wayback Machine {{Trump businesses}} [[Category:Business career of Donald Trump]] [[Category:Nutritional supplement companies]] [[Category:Defunct multi-level marketing companies]] [[Category:American companies established in 1997]] [[Category:1997 establishments in Massachusetts]] [[Category:Defunct companies based in Massachusetts]] [[Category:2012 disestablishments in the United States]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2012}} [[File:Малкин Виталий Борисович.jpg|thumb|Vitaly Malkin]] '''Vitaly Borisovich Malkin''' ({{lang-ru|Виталий Борисович Малкин}}) (born 16 September 1952) is a Russian-Israeli [[business oligarch]] and politician who was born in [[Pervouralsk]] near [[Ekaterinburg]] in central Russia, the administrative center of [[Sverdlovsk Oblast]]. He is married and has three children. His fortune is estimated by ''Forbes'' to be $1 billion.
==Business/political career== Malkin built his fortune in the banking sector, notably with his business partner [[Bidzina Ivanishvili]]. The two men founded [[Rossiysky Kredit]], which was the third largest Russian bank until the financial crisis of 1998.<ref>[http://www.zoominfo.com/people/Malkin_Vitaly_633387564.aspx Zoom Info Business, Vitaly Malkin]</ref> He has been a member of Russian Senate since 2004 and is now officially retired from business.<ref>[https://www.forbes.com/lists/2008/10/billionaires08_Vitaly-Malkin_5DJW.html Vitaly Malkin, Forbes 2008 billionaires list]</ref> He represents the east Siberian republic of [[Buryatia]] in the Federation Council since 2004.<ref>[http://www.moscowtimes.ru/articles/detail.php?ID=378307 Moscow Times - Billionaire Senator Can't Get Canadian Visa]</ref> In 2012, headed a delegation of four Russian senators in Washington lobbying against the [[Magnitsky Act]]. Vitaly Malkin and his colleagues tried to convince American senators that [[Sergei Magnitsky]] was a criminal and that he died from pancreatitis.<ref>[https://www.forbes.com/sites/markadomanis/2012/07/13/oleg-kashins-dismissive-take-on-the-russian-delegations-visit-to-washington/ Oleg Kashin's Dismissive Take on the Russian Delegation's Visit to Washington], Forbes, 13 July 2012</ref>
==Controversy== According to the ''National Post'' (Canada), Malkin was denied entry to Canada in May 2009 after a 15-year legal dispute. The Canadian government has accused him of involvement in alleged money laundering and international arms deals.<ref>[http://www.nationalpost.com/news/story.html?id=1656093 "Oligarch Vitaly Malkin just can't get into Canada"], ''National Post'', 2 June 2009 {{Dead link|date=January 2010}}</ref>
In 2013 Russian anti-corruption activist [[Alexey Navalny]] published documents in his blog, showing that Malkin has failed to declare ownership of 111 condominiums in Canada and that he has an Israeli passport.<ref>[http://www.themoscowtimes.com/news/article/navalny-targets-senator-malkin/476967.html#ixzz2OuL9y3Y6 Navalny Targets Senator Malkin]</ref>
Malkin resigned from Federation Council amid his double nationality scandal.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.jta.org/news/article/2013/03/27/3123091/russian-senator-resigns-over-accusations-of-israeli-citizenship |title=Archived copy |access-date=29 March 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130330092952/http://www.jta.org/news/article/2013/03/27/3123091/russian-senator-resigns-over-accusations-of-israeli-citizenship |archive-date=30 March 2013 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref>

'''Winnie Liljeborg''' (formerly Winnie Dahl and Winnie Enevoldsen) is a [[Denmark|Danish]] businesswoman, investor and philanthropist. She was one of the founders of [[Pandora (jewelry)|Pandora]] and is now one of the wealthiest women in Denmark with a net worth of [[Danish krone|DKK]] 4.9 billion.
==Career== Winnie Liljeborg founded Pandora in collaboration with her partner and later husband Per Enevoldsen in 1979. The private equity fund [[Axcel]] purchased 60% of the company in 2006.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://finans.dk/erhverv/ECE9528530/winnie-liljeborg-er-gavmild-selvskabt-milliardaer-og-blandt-danmarks-rigeste/?ctxref=ext|title=Winnie Liljeborg er gavmild, selvskabt milliardær og blandt Danmarks rigeste|language=Danish|website=finans.dk|accessdate=14 September 2017}}</ref>
==Philanthropy== In 2014, she purchased the property [[Haraldsborg]] in [[Roskilde]] and has subsequently been converting it into a [[Christmas stamp|Christmas stamp home]] (''julemærkehjem'') and school for children with weight issues.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sn.dk/Roskilde/Gigantdonation-betyder-julemaerkehjem-i-Roskilde/artikel/480360|title=Gigantdonation betyder julemærkehjem i Roskilde|language=Danish|website=sn.dk|accessdate=14 September 2017}}</ref> She has also supported Mødrehjælpen.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bt.dk/danmark/pandora-stifter-afsloeret-dansk-milliardaer-levede-dobbeltliv-i-thailand|title=Pandora-stifter afsløret: Dansk milliardær levede dobbeltliv i Thailand|language=Danish|publisher=BT|accessdate=14 September 2017}}</ref>
==Personal life== Winnie Liljeborg and Per Enevoldsen have one son, Christian. They divorced after their silver wedding anniversary in 2008. Liljeborg lives on Strandvejen in Roskilde.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ekstrabladet.dk/nyheder/erhvervsnyheder/sky-smykkedronning-er-en-af-landets-mest-velhavende-saa-rig-er-hun/6628993|title=Sky smykkedronning er en af landets mest velhavende: Så rig er hun|language=Danish|website=snEkstra Bladet|accessdate=14 September 2017}}</ref> In September 2017, [[Berlingske|Berlingske Business]] estimated her net worth at [[Danish krone|DKK]] 4.9 billions.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.business.dk/navne/21-winnie-liljeborg-rollemodel-for-kvindelige-ivaerksaettere|title=21 Winnie Liljeborg: Rollemodel for kvindelige iværksættere |language=Danish|website=Berlingske Business|accessdate=14 September 2017}}</ref>
